text: <@UFS53UWE5> Thanks for the feedback! We are still working on the messaging. RE “Move data” some love some meh LOL we like to say that businesses are simply stories data; how data moves from user to business to server to database and back (not always in that order hehe). But data from a “top-level” the business-logic level.

elements.text: Thanks for the feedback! We are still working on the messaging. RE “Move data” some love some meh LOL we like to say that businesses are simply stories data; how data moves from user to business to server to database and back (not always in that order hehe). But data from a “top-level” the business-logic level.

text: We are trying to position ourselves as the first business-logic language. Sure you can write business-logic in Python, but we are trying to show the world why Storyscript is better for BPM/logic and why Python (and all other languages) are better for data processing/algorithms/etc. — Storyscript is the most inclusive language because it’s polyglot development in a distributed monolith.

elements.text: We are trying to position ourselves as the first business-logic language. Sure you can write business-logic in Python, but we are trying to show the world why Storyscript is better for BPM/logic and why Python (and all other languages) are better for data processing/algorithms/etc. — Storyscript is the most inclusive language because it’s polyglot development in a distributed monolith.

text: Sorry, I was pretty sleepy when I sent that. Yes, it worked; my aim was a single function to remove a column from a table. I deliberately went the long way round, creating `delcol` out of a few smaller functions, so as to experiment with composability and other UX.

text: I think that makes more sense! I didn't get the fact that it's polyglot, or perhaps that didn't click when I read it. Sounds like a cool project!

text:
I don't have much time right now, so here's a quick précis of feedback points. Note that I did all my dev in the "Try" page rather than installing Maraca for myself, which had its ups and downs.
1. Function composition comes out looking a bit odd, and could do with improvements, but isn't terrible. Instead of nesting calls I could have easily stored individual call results in keys, which would be much more readable. Still, a nicer way to chain would be good.
2. More debuggability, as ever, would help hugely. Main issues are the lack of helpful error messages or debug mode which shows me intermediate states.
3. There's no commenting syntax, either for adding docs or temporarily disabling code. Do you have a plan or recommendation here?
4. The docs for Unpacking and Map functions, and assignment to streams, could really do with expansion & clarification. I had to experiment with both for a while before properly understanding them.
5. I like the idea of keeping the core syntax fairly minimal and supplying most functions in the custom library. I suspect you'll need some form of namespacing here though... unless you literally just use spaces for subscripting into a library dict of functions? In which case, function application may look even messier. (Not sure about this yet. I'm still wrapping my head around being able to use spaces in names.)

elements.text:
I don't have much time right now, so here's a quick précis of feedback points. Note that I did all my dev in the "Try" page rather than installing Maraca for myself, which had its ups and downs.
1. Function composition comes out looking a bit odd, and could do with improvements, but isn't terrible. Instead of nesting calls I could have easily stored individual call results in keys, which would be much more readable. Still, a nicer way to chain would be good.
2. More debuggability, as ever, would help hugely. Main issues are the lack of helpful error messages or debug mode which shows me intermediate states.
3. There's no commenting syntax, either for adding docs or temporarily disabling code. Do you have a plan or recommendation here?
4. The docs for Unpacking and Map functions, and assignment to streams, could really do with expansion & clarification. I had to experiment with both for a while before properly understanding them.
5. I like the idea of keeping the core syntax fairly minimal and supplying most functions in the custom library. I suspect you'll need some form of namespacing here though... unless you literally just use spaces for subscripting into a library dict of functions? In which case, function application may look even messier. (Not sure about this yet. I'm still wrapping my head around being able to use spaces in names.)

text: Interesting. At first glance there are some new ideas here. <@UJDQKSSJ0> I’d recommend a one-page summary of the cool features, perhaps in a 2-column format comparing to JS/React

text: <@UFV8P4472> thanks again for taking the time to dig in properly, and for all the feedback :slightly_smiling_face: one quick thing before I reply to your points, I think you maybe missed that you can do argument destructuring for functions, ie you could have written `del: [[l, k]=> l?.[v=>> (v? ! k?, v?)]]`, rather than needing to pull out `l` and `k` manually

, rather than needing to pull out

text: Yep, totally missed that. Thank you!

elements.text: Yep, totally missed that. Thank you!

text:
1. I think simple chaining comes out quite nicely (e.g. `[1, 2, 3].[v=>> v? + 1].[v=>> v? * 2]`), but yes in your example the nested function calls get somewhat cluttered. I guess this is partly from choosing to prioritise strings as values rather than variables, and hence needing lots of ?s. Do you have a good example from another language that handles nested function calls really nicely? Just to help me think about it.
2. Yep agree completely, just haven’t worked on it yet!
3. So there actually is a very basic comment syntax which I forgot to document - anything between a pair of backticks will evaluate to nil, so you can do that as a list item to make a comment (as long as you’re not in a () semilist). I’ve wanted to have Prettier working with Maraca from the start, so that makes arbitrary comments much harder / possibly not a good idea, as they need to fit into the ast. Still something that needs work for sure though, any thoughts welcome.
4. Ok thanks, I’ll take a look at those bits and see if I can make them clearer.
5. As you say, relates to the chaining thing. You can have something like `#math.cos.2` which I think it pretty simple, but I haven’t tried pushing it very far yet.

I’ve wanted to have Prettier working with Maraca from the start, so that makes arbitrary comments much harder / possibly not a good idea, as they need to fit into the ast. Still something that needs work for sure though, any thoughts welcome.

#math.cos.2
which I think it pretty simple, but I haven’t tried pushing it very far yet.

text: <@U6KQ2S410> Thank you, it felt like a few things came together in ways I hadn’t seen elsewhere, but it’s nice to hear from someone with a fuller knowledge of the field! And yes that sounds like a really good idea - it’s been a process of making the core design choices and then working through to the logical conclusions, so it’ll be interested to do a direct comparison back to JS/React now I’m towards the end of that.

text: Hey guys made a graphic on how different paradigms in programming languages could be related. Does this hold up to scrutiny?

elements.text: Hey guys made a graphic on how different paradigms in programming languages could be related. Does this hold up to scrutiny?

text: I like the parts I know something about. It seems like there's a directionality to the edges? Adding denotational semantics to imperative programming gives you lambda calculus? Adding axiomatic semantics gives proof systems like Dijkstra's _Discipline of Programming_? Am I interpreting it right? Probably just revealing my ignorance.

text: I'm curious where the limits are or to put it another way what happens when I try to make a more complex program? If I wanted to make Google spreadsheets what perf issues would I run into and how would I fix them. Another example might be Google Photos.
